Zachary McCarthy, a Boy Scout with Troop 608 in Hamden, has been a part of Common Ground's summer camp program for over a decade. For his Eagle Scout project he decided to raise funds and assemble picnic tables to support our outdoor classroom initiative and allow high school classes to take place outdoors in the upcoming school year.

Last Sunday, with a group of his friends and family, Zachary came to campus and built us several much needed tables. In his words, ‚ÄúPicnic tables are important for this high school because this is a very outdoors high school. Due to COVID-19 a lot of people have had to change what they do for learning and practice social distance learning and with these picnic tables the kids at this school that rely so much on outdoor learning will be able to learn outdoors in a safe social distance environment."

Thank you Zachary and Boy Scout Troop 608 in Hamden for your support and generosity. And thanks to WTNH News 8 for visiting our special campus. We are so grateful to have you as part of the Common Ground community!

Check out these wonderful 'geodrawings' made by students using technology in 2D and 3D modeling software! This year, the beloved Mr. Mo (Mel Morales) utilized nature and photography to refresh his summer program math lessons for incoming 9th grade students. He reflected on the class, "...there was so much inner child present to escape the daily stress of the current situation. My students all have talent, aspirations and so much creativity. They just need the tools to shine."

In addition to this creative use of software, for the first time in Common Ground history, we reached the milestone of successfully answering more than 300,000 math questions throughout the academic year. Just the summer camp math students alone answered more than 45,000 problems!

Despite COVID-19 disrupting in-person learning, our students and teachers remain resilient. Common Ground students -- we celebrate your dedication, progress and motivation!

Common Ground community -- please help us spread the word! Thanks to Sustainable CT, you can DOUBLE YOUR SUPPORT for our Green Jobs Corps (GJC) student leaders! GJC, led by Crystal Fernandez (former alumni turned staff member,) provides paid work for our students in sustainable agriculture and environmental justice. They plant trees, steward gardens at public schools, grow and distribute fresh produce and more.

GJC are vital and powerful contributors to our community! Unfortunately, GJC faces a very real threat. Shifts in federal funding priorities have significantly reduced support for employment programs that serve young people in school. A U.S. Department of Labor program that used to provide GJC close to $100,000 a year contributed just $24,000 in 2019-20.

This uncertainty comes amidst the pandemic which is decimating jobs in the community. Thankfully, due to the generous match offered by Sustainable CT you can double your impact and help GFC continue to provide meaningful, paid work for our students. Help us reach our goal of $15,000 dollars which will be doubled to $30,000!

post_text: Today we are honored to share the powerful poetry of our own Crystal Fernandez, Common Ground Alumni, Green Jobs Corps Manager and -- her most important title -- Mom of Four Black Latino Kings. There are so many ways Crystal enriches our Common Ground community. She is the kind of leader that never stops growing. She sees the possibility and strength in every young person, listens to their interests and passions, and connects them to the resources and support they need. She shares the following mantra with the young people she works with to encourage them to press through any trial, "You did great and you are enough. This one thing doesn't define you. Not your grades, neighborhood, family, or choices. You can always redefine yourself. Without shame." We ask you, our community, to hear her voice today and read her poem. #blacklivesmatter

OUR EARTH DAY CELEBRATION OF OUTDOOR EDUCATION CONTINUES: ‚ÄúRespect the land, and respect people. So often, the way you treat the land is how you treat people, and the way you treat people is the way you treat the land."

We were so grateful to have Dr. Thomas Easley -- forester, geneticist, hip hop artist, pastor, professor, leader in equity and inclusion -- kick off his time as Common Ground's 2020 Environmental Leader in Residence today. Dr. Easley talked with students and staff about his family roots in gardening and the civil rights movement, about going from a historically black college to being the only African American in his school of forestry, about poetry and hip hop as a way of working through loss, and about understanding the environment as "the area that cultivates you." What a powerful way to celebrate the 50th Earth Day!

We are so honored that Tammy Chapman will be teaching a class on "Herbs for Everyday Living" as part of our upcoming Winter Farm and Garden Conference. Tammy is a Newhallville community organizer, an organic gardener, wife, mother of five children and the owner and founder of The Glass Jar Natural Skincare.

"My story starts with soil. Yes, real soil. More like the smell of soil as it warms in the spring time. Those are some of my earliest sensory memories growing up with gardening. I considered myself a hobbyist of tinctures and tonics until my eldest developed severe acne. Working with the soil again and herbs helped us find long term healing for her.

Now, I'm the owner of The Glass Jar Natural Skincare Community, a bath and beauty company tailored to a variety of needs (and wants). Our product line does not use any chemicals or synthetic preservatives.

We are proud to source most of our herbal materials from area urban gardens and infuse the goodness into our products. It's a committed process from garden to bottle."

We are beyond excited that Dina Brewster, the Executive Director of CTNOFA, will be presenting at the Winter Farm and Garden Conference!

Dina has been a full-time farmer for 15 years! Committed to connecting people with working land, Dina chose to return to her family‚Äôs farm in Ridgefield and start the Community Supported Agriculture (CSA) Program, one that still exists as the backbone of the farm‚Äôs business plan. Dina believes we have a responsibility to increase the economic vitality of our regional agrarian economy, improve the long-range ecological stewardship of our land and water, and enliven our cultural commitment to farming.

Join her for "Welcome to Eco59: Planting pollinator Friendly Farms and Gardens." Learn how to use native plants to enhance the "ecosystem services" of your farm or garden. Our whole food system depends on our littlest helpers, the insects that pollinate our plants.
